stance_1: I believe chicken, turkey, and fish are healthier
stance_2: I eat chicken, turkey, and fish
justification: The belief that chicken, turkey, and fish are healthier directly supports the choice to eat those meats.

stance_1: I believe chicken, turkey, and fish are healthier
stance_2: I eat little or no beef
justification: The belief that chicken, turkey, and fish are healthier than beef supports reducing beef consumption.

stance_1: I have digestive problems with beef
stance_2: I eat little or no beef
justification: Digestive problems with beef explicitly motivate the reduction of beef consumption.

stance_1: I have digestive problems with beef
stance_2: I eat chicken, turkey, and fish
justification: Digestive problems with beef support the choice to eat other meats that do not cause issues.

stance_2: I believe chicken, turkey, and fish are healthier
justification: The desire to stay healthy supports the belief in eating healthier meats.

stance_2: I eat chicken, turkey, and fish
justification: The desire to stay healthy supports the choice of healthier meats.

justification: The desire to stay healthy supports reducing beef, which is perceived as less healthy.

stance_2: I have digestive problems with beef
justification: Digestive problems with beef are tied to health concerns which support avoiding beef.

stance_1: I eat chicken, turkey, and fish
stance_2: My wife changed her eating habits with me
justification: The interviewee's eating habits influenced his wife to also eat chicken, turkey, and fish.

stance_1: I eat little or no beef
